text: George Frederick Dallas (1827 – 2 February 1888) was an English first-class cricketer. The son of Robert William Dallas, he was born at Liverpool and was educated at Harrow School. He purchased a commission in 1845 as an ensign in the 46th Regiment of Foot, before being promoted to the rank of lieutenant in April 1848. He made his debut in first-class cricket for the Gentlemen of Kent against Cambridge University at Canterbury in 1848. He made two further first- class appearances, playing for Lancashire against Yorkshire in 1849, and for Yorkshire against an All England Eleven in 1850. Dallas served in the Crimean War from 1853-56, seeing action at Alma, Balaclava, Inkerman and the Siege of Sevastopol. During the course of the war he purchased the rank of captain in September 1854, as well as serving as the aide-de-camp to General Garrett. He wrote an eyewitness account of the war, consisting of 127 letters. He was made a member of the Order of the Medjidie, 5th Class, by the Ottoman Empire in March 1858. He later purchased the rank of major in October 1862, before being promoted to the rank of lieutenant in January 1868. He retired from active service in March 1875. Dallas died at Huddersfield in February 1888. ==References== ==External links== * Category:1827 births Category:1888 deaths Category:Sportspeople from Liverpool Category:People educated at Harrow School Category:English cricketers Category:Gentlemen of Kent cricketers Category:Lancashire cricketers Category:Yorkshire cricketers Category:46th Regiment of Foot officers Category:British Army personnel of the Crimean War Category:Recipients of the Order of the Medjidie, 5th class Category:Military personnel from Liverpool
title: George Dallas (cricketer)
